message: In my experience, they're not a threat, just aggressive sales folks sometimes. Just grow a backbone and do what you think is right for you. I personally prefer buying stuff from the people being creative - not the guys saying they need money for a bus home (unless it's true and that "bus home" can be smoked.)

Why don't you do something about it?  I spend my free time volunteering at shelters educating homeless kids.  Spend Thanksgiving working a Soup Kitchen.  Give them your doggie bag from the restaurant.  There is so much you can do to help the homeless.  If you support them, help them, give them opportunities suddenly they are no longer homeless.  Ergo, no more problem.
@BikerBecca I have an idea how to get homeless off the street, but it requires architects. Help?
@operator - I love your idea.  Sadly I don't know any architects but I will absolutely keep it in mind.  Sounds even better than my efforts.  Be Well ~Becca

As a San Francisco native, I can tell you that 90% of the homeless problem is not people who are looking for help, its people who are looking to scam regular people. SF has tended to coddle the scam artists rather than helping the people who actually need help, thusly we've ended up with a huge problem. There's not much of a solution aside from registering the indigent (eew) or just ignoring the problem altogether.

@operator I propose a regional solution. Out of the 9 counties San Francisco shoulders the greatest burden compared to our sister city to the south, San Jose. Take the current, well beyond generous programs in SF and move sone of them south. Also, the multi-national corporations which hire suburbanites and leach off of our city should be mandated to solving this issue in our city. They have the resources, and shouldn't be greedy about it.
